From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: korn

Czech

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): [ˈkorn]

Proper noun

[edit]

Korn m anim (female equivalent Kornová)

  1. a male surname

Declension

[edit]
Declension of Korn (hard masculine animate)
singular plural
nominative Korn Kornové
genitive Korna Kornů
dative Kornovi Kornům
accusative Korna Korny
vocative Korne Kornové
locative Kornovi Kornech
instrumental Kornem Korny

Further reading

[edit]
  • “Korn”, in Příjmení.cz (in Czech)

Dutch

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

First attested as den Korne in 1542. Derived from the hydronym Korn.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kɔrn/
  • Hyphenation: Korn
  • Rhymes: -ɔrn

Proper noun

[edit]

Korn n

  1. a hamlet in Altena, North Brabant, Netherlands

References

[edit]
  • van Berkel, Gerard; Samplonius, Kees (2018), Nederlandse plaatsnamen verklaard (in Dutch), Mijnbestseller.nl, →ISBN

German

[edit]

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kɔrn/, [kɔʁn], [kɔɐ̯n], [kɔːn]
  • Audio (Germany (Berlin)):(file)

Etymology 1

[edit]

From Middle High German korn, from Old High German korn, from Proto-West Germanic *korn, from Proto-Germanic *kurną, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵr̥h₂nóm.

Noun

[edit]

Korn n (strong, genitive Kornes or Korns, plural Körner, diminutive Körnchen n or Körnlein n or Körndl n)

  1. (countable) kernel; single grain
  2. (uncountable) cereal; corn; grain (type of plant and its fruit)
    Synonym: Getreide
  3. (uncountable, dated or regional) rye (as the most common kind of grain in German-speaking Europe)
    Synonym: Roggen
  4. (countable, firearms) bead (knob on a gun barrel used for aiming)
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Korn [neuter, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein das Korn die Körner
genitive eines des Kornes, Korns der Körner
dative einem dem Korn, Korne1 den Körnern
accusative ein das Korn die Körner

1Now rare, see notes.

Related terms
[edit]
  • Dinkelkorn
  • Feinkorn
  • Gerstenkorn
  • Goldkorn
  • Grobkorn
  • Haferkorn
  • Kimme und Korn
  • Kornbrand
  • körnerfressend
  • Kornfeld
  • Korngröße
  • Kümmelkorn
  • Mehlkorn
  • Paradieskörner
  • Pfefferkorn
  • Saatkorn
  • Salzkorn
  • Sandkorn
  • Senfkorn
  • Vogelkorn
  • Vollkorn
  • Weizenkorn

Etymology 2

[edit]

Shortened from Kornbrand, whose full form is now rare.

Noun

[edit]

Korn m (strong, genitive Korns, plural (servings) Korn or (varieties) Korne or Korns)

  1. Korn (liquor produced from fermented cereal grain seed)
    Synonym: Klarer
    • 1902, Gustav Falke, “Thies und Ose”, in Hohe Sommertage‎[1]:
      In Wenningstedt bei Karten und Korn / Erschlug einst ein Bauer in jähem Zorn / Seinen Gast.
      In Wenningstedt, over cardgames and korn / A farmer once slew in sudden wrath / His guest.
    • 2021, “Wenn Du Bock hast”‎[2]performed by MaxUhu & Bangermin:
      Stephan, wenn du noch Bock hast oder so / Kannste ma’ rumkommen / Dir noch ma’n Korn abholen / Aber wenn du Bock hast / Kannst dir noch ’n Korn abholen / Wenn du Bock hast / Hab noch Korn hier.
      Stephan, if you’re up for it or summat / You can come round / Fetch yourself some korn / But if you’re up for it / You can fetch yourself some korn / If you’re up for it / I still got korn here.
Declension
[edit]
Declension of Korn [masculine, strong]
singular plural
indef. def. noun def. noun
nominative ein der Korn die Korn, Korne, Korns
genitive eines des Korns der Korn, Korne, Korns
dative einem dem Korn den Korn, Kornen, Korns
accusative einen den Korn die Korn, Korne, Korns
Related terms
[edit]
  • Apfelkorn
  • Doppelkorn
  • Weizenkorn
  • Kornbrand

Etymology 3

[edit]

Cognate with Luxembourgish Kuer.

Proper noun

[edit]

Korn f (proper noun, genitive Korn)

  1. Chiers (river)
Derived terms
[edit]
  • Niederkorn
  • Oberkorn

Further reading

[edit]
  • “Korn” in Digitales Wörterbuch der deutschen Sprache

Hunsrik

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle High German and Old High German korn, from Proto-West Germanic *korn.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /kʰɔn/

Noun

[edit]

Korn n (plural Kerner, diminutive Kernche)

  1. kernel

Derived terms

[edit]
  • Kornblumm

Further reading

[edit]
  • Boll, Piter Kehoma (2021), “Korn”, in Dicionário Hunsriqueano Riograndense–Português, 3rd edition (overall work in Portuguese), Ivoti: Riograndenser Hunsrickisch

Plautdietsch

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Middle Low German and Old Saxon korn, from Proto-West Germanic *korn.

Noun

[edit]

Korn m

  1. corn
